result.markdown:
R-ArcGIS Bridge is a powerful framework that you can use to solve complex problems by combining cutting-edge statistical models with R and ArcGIS for spatial data access, visualization, and analysis.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(arcgis)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Attaching core arcgis packages:
  - {arcgisutils} v0.1.0
  - {arcgislayers} v0.1.0
```
:::
:::



## Packages



::: {layout="[1,1]"}


::: {.card}
`{arcgisbinding}`

Harness the power of ArcGIS Pro from R.
:::

::: {.card}
`{arcgis}`

Read and write to Feature Services and much more with ArcGIS Location Services.
:::

:::


## Not sure where to start?

- Create R based Geoprocessing tools
- Access your enterprise geodatabase from R
- Interact with ArcGIS Online and Portal 


### Vignettes & Tutorials

- ArcGIS binding tutorials 
  - https://github.com/R-ArcGIS/R-Bridge-Tutorial-Notebooks/
  - TODO: convert these to markdown
- R-Sample GP tools:
  - https://github.com/R-ArcGIS/r-sample-tools



(for now start with combined liks because we lack content )

Analogous to Python API     
Vignette -> Guide
Tutorial -> Sample

(this would hyper link to written tutorials)
These could correspond to workflows / tutorial



Tutorial/Workflow vs Vignette

- Tutorial would be a end to end process
  - read in, manipulate, etc, then write back up to online
  - How to batch geocode and upload results to AGOL 
  - How to create a GP tool (best practices)
  - Read from an enterprise geodatabase / sde file
  - using R for something specific that you dont do in pro (for binding) or analysis tools
- Vignette: how to understand / interact with a specific piece of code
  - authorization
  - creating new packages 
    - tips for developers
